msgSnippet: ... Well, there is only the constructor that takes a test name and an expected exception class, so your constructor must pass the expected exception class up
messageBody:
>So said Lucas on 2003-05-23 --------------------
>J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
>> I checked the source. The constructor is public.
>
>I dont understand, I still get
>
>Error The constructor ExceptionTestCase(String) is
>undefined
>
>when I add the normal TestCase constructor:
>
> public Exception1Test(String arg0) {
> super(arg0);
> }

Well, there is only the constructor that takes a test name and an expected exception class, so your constructor must pass the expected exception class up to its superclass' constructor.

>> 1. Are you using JUnit 3.8.1?
>
>I saw it's 3.7

I doubt it's different.

>but as you recommended, I won't use it.
>I am familiar with the traditional way. I thought there is a benefit but
>as I
>saw in ExceptionTestCaseTest it's about the same programming effort but a
>weird construction.

I agree.

>I think it should be removed from the junit.extensions, it's distracting.

I also agree.
